newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian debt sees rate cut as inevitable move.
newsitem.headline: Australian debt sees rate cut as inevitable move.

text.p: *The Australian debt market closed firm amid strong expectations that the RBA will have to ease policy again if it wants to meet its growth expectations.

The absence of a cut in official interest rates by the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) on Friday made little impression on the Australian debt market which is still looking for an easing sooner rather than later.

Thursday's extremely weak labour force data fuelled calls for an easing in current official 5.5 percent interest rates if the Australian authorities are serious in achieving growth and the market will be on full alert until such a moves happens.
The September bill futures contract pulled back from an early high of 94.92, but is still practically pricing in a 1/2 point cut in rates by maturity.

The market showed a widening bias against the dollar bloc after Thursday's sharp narrowing, particularly at the short end after rates were left on hold. Canadian debt was strong on waning fears of a Fed tightening and the 30-year spread to the U.S. went to a negative for the first time.
